thesis.description: This is a morphological study of the bark beetle Dendroetonus monticolae Hopk. It involves the external anatomy of the adult beetle, the reproductive system and the digestive tract. A discussion of the evolution of the Rhyncbophorous head is given in which the controversial points of various workers are mentioned. An explanation of the hypostoma and the tentorium is given aecording to the writer's interpretation. The thoracic segments are discussed from an outer and an inner aspect. The mesotergum is peculiar in its enlarged precosta and prescutum and specialized scutum and scutellum. The abdomen presents the most important sexual characters which are found in the location and shape of the seventh and eighth terigites. In the female, 8 Is covered by 7, and forms the so-called "pygidium" while in the male 8 is distinct and together with 7 forms the so-called "divided pygidium". It is thought that the ninth and tenth tergites and the ninth and tenth sternites are represented in the sclerotized elements of the reproductive organs. The appendages ot the body are figured with their means of articulation explained. [...]
thesis.creator: Richmond, Hector Allan.
thesis.subject: Entomology.
thesis.title: A morphological study of the bark beetle - Dendroctonus monticolae Hopk.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A careful search of the 1iterature concerning the fishes of the fresh-waters of Canada shows that studies of an ichthyological nature of the fresh-waters of the Province of Quebec in the past have been restricted to accounts of small collections made only within small areas. These are typically incomplete. To the present time there has not appeared a full account of-the species inhabiting the freshwaters of this Province based on studies and collections made over a wide range. [...]

thesis.subject: Freshwater fishes -- Qu√©bec (Province)

thesis.description: The struggle was caused by the Church of England's claim to exclusive establishment in the colonies. It was contended that the Church was established by the Act of Union, 1707, Royal 1nstructions to the Governors, the Quebec Act, 1774, and the Canada Act, 1791. Establishrnent meant legal recognition as the only Protestant Church having the right to perform civil acts, to be incorporated, to control education and to receive government financial support. To these pretensions the Kirk, as the established Church of Scotland madeobjection. [...]

thesis.subject: Church of England in Canada.
Presbyterian Church in Canada.
History.
Canada -- Church history.
thesis.title: The struggle of the Church of Scotland for equal rights and privileges with the Church of England in Lower Canada.

thesis.description: The polymerization of primary "building units" is a fundamental chemical reaction, and finds extensive application, particularly in industrial fields. Many simple chemical substances are valueless from an industrial standpoint until converted by polymerization processes into compounds which, owing to their greater stability and more desirable physicalproperties, have application in a great variety of industries. The most common examples are the plastic and lacquer industries where many products, formerly of very limited use, are now converted on a large scale into materials from which a great number of useful objects are manufactured. [...]
thesis.creator: Pullman, Joseph Cyril.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Synthesis and properties of polyethylene ether glycols.

thesis.description: With the development of psychological tests by which an individual's ability may, within limits, be measured, numerous problems have come to light, problems which were previously not fully recognized. Prior to this time children who were unable to learn to read were classified as dull or even feebleminded and no real attempt was made to help them overcome their difticulty. Later it was found that many who possessed average or superior intelligence were quite unable to learn to read in spite of any amount of instruction of the ordinary type. This was a startling tact which, when realized, opened up a new field for investigation. [...]
thesis.creator: Peden, Gwendolyn Winnifred.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: A study of reading disability.

thesis.description: This thesis covers several individual investigations. Section I. The responses of frogs, intact and operated, to turn-table rotation, have been graphically registered. Section II. Two equilibrial reactions, hitherto obtained only from frogs with labyrinthine operations, have been found to occur in normal frogs. [...]

thesis.description: The writer points out the profound influence which the railways, as "equalisers of opportunity," have had in creating and maintaining the existing economic structure of Canada and how the recent development of competition from motor transport and in lesser degree, air transport, threatens to make it impossible for them to continue this function, with serious consequences to the economic life of the nation. After a discussion of the vexed question of motor vehicle taxation and of the various means which might be taken to meet the growing competition from motor transport, it is concluded that the rationalisation of railway services (closer co-operation between our two great railway systems, or even their complete amalgamation, and the adoption of new units of railway rolling stock, such as the rail-car and oil-electric train), and the initiation of supplementary and auxiliary highway services by the railways offer the only practical solution. [...]
thesis.creator: Rollit, John Buchanan.
thesis.subject: Transportation -- Canada.
Economics.
thesis.title: Transportation as a national problem.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis is the report of a survey of the iron foundries of a company which manufactures chilled cast-iron car wheels, brake shoes, and grey iron castings. The first part includes: (1) an analysis of the markets for the products of this plant, including a forecast of the probable developments of the immediate future, and (2) an examination of the influence of drastic fluctuations in business activity on policies concerning the installation of capital equipment. [...]

thesis.subject: Mechanical Engineering.
thesis.title: The re-design of an iron foundry.

thesis.description: Why do plants winterkill? How are some able to withstand the coldest temperatures while others are destroyed by the first touch of frost? As early as 1727, Stephen Hales attempted to answer these questions. "Plants of a less durable texture1", he states, "as they abound with a greater proportion of Salt and Water, which is not so strongly attractingas sulphur and air, so are they less able to resist the cold; and as plants are observed to have a greater proportion of Salt and Water in them in the spring, than in the autumn,so are they more easily injured by cold in the spring, than in a more advanced age, when their quantity of oil is increased, with their greater maturity". [...]

thesis.subject: Plant physiology.
Botany.
thesis.title: Cellular changes associated with the hardening of plants.

In this we have the six elements, separate or combined, of universal literature three of which, History, Philosophy and Rhetoric, correspond to the other three Epic, Lyric and Dramatic poetry. (1) [...]

thesis.description: The effect of the physical conditions upon the alkaline digestion of wood for the production of cellulose-pulp have been experimentally investigated. The factors which were examined included the effect of wood species, density, moisture content, chip size, wood structure, method of liquor penetration and temperature. From a consideration of the manner in which the reaction rate varies with the base and its concentration, two salient factors have been suggested as governing the mechanism of the alkaline delignification of wood. These are the magnitude of the adsorption and the activity of the base. Hydroxyl ion concentration, nature of the solvent and diffusion enter only insofar as they affect the above two factors. [...]
thesis.creator: Larocque, Gerard Louis.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The influence of adsorption and the physical properties of alkaline liquors on the mechanism of cooking of wood.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Progress in the biochemistry of digestive secretions in general, and of gastric juice in particular, is in no way to be compared with the rapid advances made in the other branches of this science. Be it due to the experimental difficulties, which are considerable indeed, or to lack of interest, the fact is that very little is known concerning the chemical composition of these extremely important secretions. As to the composition of the gastric juice, the view expressed by Rosemann in 1927 still may be considered as the one generally accepted. [...]
thesis.creator: Komarov, Simon Andrew.
thesis.subject: Physiology.
thesis.title: Chemical and physiological investigation on organic constituents of gastric juice.

thesis.description: The breccias occurring in the vicinity of Montreal are among the most interesting geological features of the region. It is not surprising, therefore, that these rocks have received much attention from geologists during the last eighty years, and that they have formed the subject of several publications. Excellent though these works may be, they are largely descriptive and concern themselves chiefly with the petrography of the matrices and inclusions and with the palaeontology of fossils in fragments contained in the breccia. [...]
thesis.creator: Grimes-Graeme, R. C. H.
thesis.subject: Geology.
thesis.title: The origin of the intrusive igneous breccias in the vicinity of Montreal, Que.

thesis.description: After the passing of centuries, it is often difficult, even well-nigh impossible, to come to a definite decision with regard to certain phases of everyday life amongst the ordinaryfolk of ancient peoples, if archaeological remains are not very helpful and literary references few and far between. Thus it follows that the question as to the wide-spread prevalence of many customs is one which we are often content to settle by an occasional misinterpreted statement, or at least by two or three chance references which, perhaps, were the exception rather than the establiehed rule. Take for instanoe the practice of human sacrifice amongst Greeks and Romans. [...]
thesis.creator: Grant, Mary Jean.
thesis.subject: Classics.
thesis.title: The exposure of infants in ancient Greece from Homeric to Christian times.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Of all the injurious insects, the Scolytidae are certainly among those which were most thoroughly studied by entomologists. For all that, however, about the only thing we know on the majority of those insects, is what has been written in the original description. Indeed, in Amerlica, apart from some species belonging to the genus Dendroctonus which have been quite well worked out, most of the others were rather considered as of secondary economic importance and their study has been neglected. [...]

thesis.title: Biology of Ips Perturbats Eichoff.

thesis.description: The world for the past five years has presented a curious spectacle. Each nation has been desperately trying to give away its goods by bounties mn exports, depreciation of the currency and a lowering of the general wage-scale while at the same time endeavouring to stop the incoming flow of goods across its frontiers by means of quotas, sanitary regularions and ever-mounting tariffs. The net result of all thi s has been a definitely poorer world. [...]

thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: French economic self-sufficiency.

thesis.description: Sucrose, which is commercially known as sugar, is found in a large number of vegetable products. Two plants, however, supply practically all the world's sugar. These are the sugar-cane, grown in tropical countries, and the sugar beet, grown in Europe, the United states and Canada. As this problem is only concerned with cane sugar, the cultivation andmanufacture of beet sugar will not be considered. [...]

thesis.title: The redesign of a sugar mill.

thesis.description: The histologic features of the following diseases have been studied: (1) Delphinium Black Spot, caused by Bacterium delphini (E.F.Smith) Bryan. (2) Cauliflower Leaf Spot, caused by Bacterium maculicola (McC.) McCulloch. (3) Black Rot of Crucifers, caused by Bacterium campestre (Pam.) E.F.S. (4) Fireblight of Apples and Pears, caused by Bacillus amylovorus (Burrill) Trevisan. (5) Bacterial Blight of Bean, caused by Bacterium phaseoli E.F.Smith. (6) Beet Leaf Spot, caused by Cercospora beticola Sacc. The most important findings were in connection with cicatrice formation. In (2) and (6) active disease resistance responses, including occlusion of the intercellular spaces and, under warm Bonditions, the formation of wound cork round the lesions, were observed. In the remaining diseases active resistance responses were not noted except in a few cases which appeared to be abnormal. Wounding tests on leaves of cauliflower, turnip, cabbage, bean and beet indicated their ability to form wound cork similar to that formed round disease lesions. [...]
thesis.creator: Savile, D. B. O.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Histologic changes induced by certain phytopathogens.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis presents a brief review of the cbildhood, early manhood and character of Pierre Loti before visiting Turkey. The five visits of Loti to Turkey are discussed, particularly in their relationship to the influence they have on the character and mental outlook of the man. Loti's impressions of Turkey, its people, their social customs and their religion are compared with those of contemporary writers on Turkey. Finally, the description of the Turkish women and her life in the harem as depicted in "Les Desenchantees", is considered, and the question discussed as to whether it is truly representative of the Turkish woman of that day.
thesis.creator: Rexford, Laura H.
thesis.subject: Loti, Pierre, 1850-1923 -- Travel -- Turkey.
French.
Turkey -- Description and travel.
thesis.title: Pierre Loti et la Turquie.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The effects of solutions of hydrochloric pcid, acetic acid and lactic acid, isotonic with blood, upon the motility of the small gut of the cat and dog, when introduced into the gut lumen, were investigated. A Experiments in which cats were employed: In a series of experiments in which the acids all had the same pH of 2.5, acetic acid was the most effectivemotor stimulant, while lactic acid was more effective than hydrochloric acid. Physostigmine and choline emphasized these relationships. [...]

thesis.description: The extraction of "glycol lignin" by use of glycol containing 0.05% HCI has been investigated, new methods for the purification described, and the methoxyl contents shown to be 16.5 - 16% (and not 18.5, as previously reported). Fractionation gave two isomeric components. The indirect evidence for the presence of a glycol radicle in "glycol lignin" has been confirmed. [...]

thesis.title: The structure and properties of glycol lignin.

thesis.description: This survey, which is primarily concerned with Great Britain, presents various accounts and explanations of the economic fluctuations experienced between the years 1800 and 1914. Quotations from annual reviews, periodicals and a few histories make up the greater part of the work. Most of the extracts given are from writings composed at a time contemporary to, or shortly after the occurrence of the events discussed in them. The purpose of the study is to indicate economic conditions in the period considered, and to assist in reaching a clearer understanding of the nature of economic f1uctuations. [...]
thesis.creator: Gilroy, Geoffrey.
thesis.subject: Economics.
Business cycles.
Business cycles -- Great Britain.
thesis.title: A historical survey of economic fluctuations, 1800-1914.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
